subject: Testing an arbitrary number of conditions.

messageBody:
You guys might be able to help me.

I want to be able to determine dynamically the number of tests that
should be run. I have a number of tests to run that certain conditions
are met in the execution of a components. I don't want to write a test
per test condition because I don't know how many will be needed and I
don't want to rewrite the tests for each added (or removed condition). I
guess this resembles most closely an array contents test however I don't
know how many elements are present and the array equality argument
doesn't apply:

The problem ofcourse is that if I loop through n conditions in a test,
the first one that fails will complete that test method but I want to
report multiple failures. The overall failure of the collection of
conditions is not a fine grained enough a report.

Any ideas, pointers?

thanks

chanoch

Mert,

Please read all of the documentation. To write a test, you simply
extend TestCase, add your "public void testYYY()" methods. You can then
run this test case with anyone of the several TestRunners. You can also
look at J.B.'s excellent starter guide at
www.diasparsoftware.com/articles/JUnit/jUnitStarterGuide.html.

=jason

On Tue, 2002-08-13 at 20:11, Mert Nuhoglu wrote: Hello,

I am a beginner to the JUnit framework. I didn't understand an issue
about the theory of JUnit.

The test methods defined in a TestCase class are supposed to override
the runTest method. How do they do that?

Let me explain what I understood. There are two ways:

1. According to the Adapter pattern with anonymous inner classes, each
test method is a subclass of the TestCase class.

Quotation 1 (from A Cook's Tour):
TestCase test= new MoneyTest("testMoneyEquals ") {
protected void runTest() { testMoneyEquals(); }
};

Here runTest method is explicitly overridden. But where is this code
segment written? Inside the static suite method?

2. According to the Pluggable Selector pattern, runTest method of
TestCase class of the JUnit framework handles everything. Right?

Quotation 2 (from A Cook's Tour):
protected void runTest() throws Throwable {
Method runMethod= null;
try {
runMethod= getClass().getMethod(fName, new Class[0]);
} catch (NoSuchMethodException e) {
assert("Method \""+fName+"\" not found", false);
}
try {
runMethod.invoke(this, new Class[0]);
}
// catch InvocationTargetException and IllegalAccessException
}

As far as I understood, runTest method reads somehow the name of the
test methods and invokes them.

I would appreciate for your explanations...

Best Regards.
Mert Nuhoglu
